title: Student Sense of Community in Quantitative Sciences (SOCQS)
text:
Principal Investigators

Dr. Maria Tackett is an Assistant Professor of the Practice in the Department of Statistical Science at Duke University. Her current work focuses on understanding how active learning strategies can be used to promote engagement and student motivation in undergraduate statistics courses. She also studies how classroom practices in introductory math and statistics courses impact students’ sense of community, self-efficacy, and learning outcomes. Maria is an RStudio certified trainer and is actively involved in the R and statistics education communities.


Dr. Shira Viel is an Assistant Professor of the Practice in the Department of Statistical Science at Duke University. Her current work focuses on understanding how active learning strategies can be used to promote engagement and student motivation in undergraduate statistics courses. She also studies how classroom practices in introductory math and statistics courses impact students’ sense of community, self-efficacy, and learning outcomes. Maria is an RStudio certified trainer and is actively involved in the R and statistics education communities.

This project is funded by the Carry the Innovation Forward Grant from Duke Learning Innovation.

title: Undergraduate Students’ Sense of Community in Introductory Math and Statistics Courses
Student Sense of Community in Quantitative Sciences (SOCQS)
text: To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: Undergraduate Students’ Sense of Community in Introductory Math and Statistics Courses
text:
Abstract
To increase diversity and representation in statistics and in STEM at large, it is essential that students can envision themselves as contributing members of these fields. Therefore, it is crucial to understand the student experience in introductory classes, as it is there that students first assess whether they can successfully pursue a particular major or career. In this session, we will present results from research on undergraduate students’ sense of community and belonging in in-person, hybrid, and online introductory math and statistics courses. We will provide a brief overview of the project that started in Fall 2020, describe the survey instrument and focus group protocol used for data collection, and present results including classroom practices associated with a higher sense of community. Participants will have the opportunity to share their experiences and exchange ideas about what has worked to foster community and belonging in their own courses.
Link to eCOTS 2022 program.

title: 2020 - 2021 Focus Group Themes
text:
In particular, the more coding references made to that theme the larger the rectangle. Click on a large rectangle (e.g., “Relationship to Peers”) to drill into it, narrowing your frame of reference to that theme and its subthemes. Subthemes which can be drilled into further are indicated with an asterisk (e.g., “Relationship to Peers|Personal Identity*). After drilling down, click on the up arrow (&#8593) in the upper-right-corner of the map to return up a level.

The interactive tree map was developed by Sarwari Das as part of the SOCQS project led by Maria Tackett and Shira Viel. This research was conducted under Duke University Campus IRB(Protocol #2021-0050) and supported by Duke Learning Innovation’s Carry the Innovation Forward program. Data were gathered from a series of 5 focus groups conducted with a total of 12 students. Transcripts were coded in NVivo.
The authors would like to thank Duke Learning Innovation, particularly Kim Manturuk, for their support facilitating the focus groups and preparing the data, as well as former Research Assistant Margaret Poulos, who developed the focus group protocol.
